thread.section_title: Business News, Economy, Finance & ASX Market News
thread.title: Property pooling reaches new heights in Melbourne
thread.title_full: Property pooling reaches new heights in Melbourne

author: Simon Johanson
title: Property pooling reaches new heights in Melbourne
text:
An artists impression of the six towers in Normanby Road.
Six Melbourne property owners have taken the idea of pooling neighbouring properties to make one large development site to a new level by banding together to create a masterplan for half a dozen 40-level skyscrapers.
The individual owners of the six adjoining sites in Fishermans Bend employed architects Hayball to design an integrated $600 million project and submitted plans for the six towers, all 40 storeys tall, with 1578 apartments last week.
Planning & Property Partners director Mark Naughton said the owners, who had held the land for long periods, felt they could get a better design outcome by working together.
Each owner had applied separately for a planning permit for their portion of the "coordinated" project, Mr Naughton said.
The resulting six-tower masterplan will stretch across a 13,000 square metre site on both sides of Normanby Road in the suburb's recently-rezoned Montague precinct.
The Montague area covers about 50 hectares and will accommodate Fishermans Bend's tallest buildings after planning minister Richard Wynne introduced lower height limits for the other pockets Lorimer, Sandridge and Wirraway.
In May Mr Wynne approved three towers rising to 46 levels in nearby Johnson Street.
Hayball architect Tom Jordan said the integrated approach had improved the public spaces between the proposed buildings by adding laneways, pocket parks and plazas.
Mr Naughton said at least one apartment in each tower would be contributed to the Port Phillip Housing Trust.
The proposed towers cover sites currently used by businesses that include South Melbourne Toyota, City Mitsubishi, Kennards Hire and Nisbets Express Catering Equipment.
